posts.name: Emmanuel Perez
posts.cooked:
Hey everyone, my team and i want to use a sensor to detect if the note is ok the index. The thing is that I already have the code written with i think the correct dio ports (Output for Echo, Input for Trigger) and my value doesn’t even move from zero, to be honest I don’t know if its a code problem or a wiring problem (we have echo, gnd and de 5V connected to pin 6, and only the trigger to pin 7).

I put a boolean on my smartdashboard to see if even the sensor is being detected, and it is. Also i tried switching at the wiring and at the code the echo and the trigger, and neither that way the value of the distance increased.

I know its a not commonly used sensor in frc things, and the only forums i found were olds with no solutions. BTW, if someone could recommend a good distance sensor with a short minimum distance like the HC-SR04 (minimum distance of 2cm) would be great. Thank you all!!

posts.name: Mert Ata BABER
posts.cooked: Can you try that sensor with an arduino just to make sure it is working? Those cheap sensors tend to be faulty.

posts.name: Dan
posts.cooked: What ranges are you testing at so far?

posts.name: Kevin Clark
posts.cooked: Can you show us the code? Are you using wpilib’s Ultrasonic sensor support or trying to roll your own?

link_counts.title: Ultrasonics - Software — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: Emmanuel Perez
posts.cooked: Hey, thanks for your response, i’ll check it in a few hours when i get to the workshop, i’ll give you an update in a couple hours. Thanks again!

posts.name: Emmanuel Perez
posts.cooked: Im trying closer and farther ranges but it doesn’t pass from 0. Also i put a boolean that tells me if its a valid range and it isn’t:(

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
US sensors are quite slow and yours recommends no faster than 60ms sampling period. Notice the Arduino program in the sensor datasheet has a one second delay between samples. If you are always at the low end of the distance range you can go faster but the longer ranges need more time. A combination of detecting near objects or not require the longer time to be sure to know the difference in detections.

The easiest test to see if your trigger is overrunning the sensor echo is increase the TimedRobot period from 20 ms default to say 100 ms or more and see if the sensor works.

You can use the addPeriodic() to get a slower pace just for this sensor.

posts.name: Emmanuel Perez
posts.cooked: Sure I can show you my code, and yes we’re using wpilib’s support

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: That just means you need to call Ultrasonic.setAutomaticMode(true); (so on the class, not the object)

posts.name: Emmanuel Perez
posts.cooked: Could you help me seeing how? Right now i just have it like this:

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: public ExampleSubsystem() { SmartDashboard.putNumber("Distancia", ultrasonicrange); Ultrasonic.setAutomaticMode(true); }

posts.name: Emmanuel Perez
posts.cooked: I have it like that, isn’t it?

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: Well, the other tweak we need to make is that the putNumber() (or whatever else is reading the distance) needs to be in the periodic() method, not the constructor, like this:

posts.name: Emmanuel Perez
posts.cooked:
Oooo you meant the Ultrasonic Class, the error did go away:)

Thank you, let me try it

posts.name: Emmanuel Perez
posts.cooked: THANKS! It work, thank you so much
